He mentioned we can't pull up the report unless we went to the station Florence to get a copy. He said he will go to the station and fax the copy to us. Send fax number via text. episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on May 1, 2023 with Jessa regarding motor vehicle accident case Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023 for client Greg Neltner.

During the call, the client was asked for the exact location of the incident so we could pull up the police report. He stated that the incident occurred in Florence KY, but he was not sure if it happened on Route 42. He said we cannot pull up the report unless we go to the Florence police station to obtain a copy. He added that he would go to the station and fax the copy to us, and he asked that the fax number be sent via text.

He also clarified his treatment, stating that he is receiving treatment from Southgate Chiropractic and that he has private health insurance.

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on August 28, 2023 with Greg Neltner regarding motor vehicle accident. Jessa spoke with Greg, who reported that he is still going to the chiropractor and has an appointment today. She advised him to let us know once he has been released.

Greg also indicated an issue with his car settlement check not being sent to the correct bank, which is leaving him still being charged for his car. Jessa advised that she would call State Farm to check on the matter.

Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner.

On October 17, 2023, the Whaley Law Firm initiated an open records request concerning Greg Neltner’s vehicle accident that occurred on April 1, 2023, seeking bodycam footage and/or photos. The request was sent by Jessa Galosmo to the internal contact GregNeltnerMVAZ3721957@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com with the email subject “Greg Neltner-Open Records Request.” The email chain includes Jessa’s initial message to Melissa Kramer, dated 9:27 AM that day, which stated: “Hi, Please see request for bodycam footage and/or photos on Greg Neltner's vehicle accident on 04/01/2023.” It was signed with Jessa Galosmo’s contact details from Whaley Law Firm: Ph: (502)357-9975 and Fax: (502)364-9363, and again repeated in the signature block.

Earlier in the day, at 9:27 AM, Jessa’s message to Melissa Kramer declared the request for bodycam footage and/or photos. In response, at approximately 10:28 AM, Brandi Roundtree, Assistant City Clerk for the City of Florence, Kentucky, replied: “Good morning, We have received your request and will process. Thank you.” Brandi Roundtree provided her city-affiliated contact information: City of Florence, 8100 Ewing Boulevard, Florence, KY 41042; phone 859.647.8177; fax 859.647.5411; email brandi.roundtree@florence-ky.gov; and website florence-ky.gov.

This exchange was then forwarded by Jessa at 10:32:10 -0400 to the relevant internal address, with the forwarded thread including Brandi Roundtree’s earlier reply and Jessa’s original message to Melissa Kramer. The forwarding header shows the chain started from Brandi Roundtree’s reply, subject “RE: Greg Neltner-Open Records Request,” sent to jessa@whaleylawfirm.com and cc’d to Melissa Kramer, followed by the earlier message from Jessa to Melissa Kramer requesting the records.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. Re: FW: PROGRESSIVE 23-6275504.

In late November 2023, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm forwarded to Progressive an attached response to Whaley’s open records request regarding the Progressive files on Greg Neltner’s motor vehicle accident matter (Progressive 23-6275504). In his message, Whaley thanked Amy Morris for the update and stated that there is no body camera footage. He emphasized that the key information is the police report, which he said chronicles what Progressive’s insured told the officer at the scene and that this account is consistent with both Progressive’s insured’s statement and Mr. Neltner’s account. He noted that Progressive’s insured says she was rear-ended, and that the police report states the same. He also highlighted what the police report claims your insured said: that she crossed three lanes of traffic to get onto the northbound I-75 ramp and, as she did so, she turned in front of Mr. Neltner. Although the officer did not witness the incident and cannot testify to what happened, Whaley stated that the officer can testify about what Progressive’s insured said, and that the officer based his liability decision on that statement. Whaley further noted that in Greg Neltner’s recorded statement he said he did not see Progressive’s insured, a detail that aligns with the accident report’s language that Progressive’s insured “suddenly turned in front of him, leaving him no time to react.” Whaley added that the damage to Progressive’s insured vehicle is listed as “7 o’clock,” which he argued would be consistent with her claimed three-lane leftward crossing.

Amy Morris replied later that day with a message dated November 30, 2023. In that reply, she stated that the situation is a word-vs-word claim at this time. She explained that Progressive’s insured asserts she was rear-ended, while the statement from Mr. Neltner’s side says he did not know what happened and did not see their vehicle. Morris noted that the police report presents a third version. She indicated Progressive was seeking body camera footage to review what was actually said and viewed at the scene of the loss, and she stated that, given the information available, Progressive was advocating for their insured.

The email thread includes earlier communications as well. On October 17, 2023, Amy Morris sent to Aaron Whaley (and Justin Whaley) a message stating, “Please see the attached formal response to the demand for Gregory Neltner.” This was accompanied by the Progressive signature block and a note that the formal response had been attached.

Earlier, on June 28, 2023, Amy Morris had written to Aaron Whaley (and others) asking whether an email address could be provided for Jessa, in the context of the Progressive matter. The June 28, 2023 messages included the standard Progressive signatures and contact details.

On November 9, 2023, Amy Morris sent another note stating that she had received a voicemail but it was unclear who it was from, and that Progressive still stood by its liability decision and was waiting to obtain bodycam footage.

On November 29, 2023, 2:05 PM, Morris again referenced the Progressive 23-6275504 matter, noting that a response had previously been sent to Aaron on October 17. The content of that November 29 note reiterates the thread’s status and the prior October 17 document.

In sum, the correspondence reveals Progressive’s position that the police report contains crucial statements attributed to their insured, including the claim that she crossed three lanes to the NB I-75 ramp and turned in front of Mr. Neltner, with the police officer basing liability on that statement. Greg Neltner’s own recorded statement asserts he did not see Progressive’s insured, aligning with the report’s characterization that she suddenly turned in front of him. The damage description on the insured’s vehicle is noted as occurring at “7 o’clock,” which aligns with the insured’s three-lane-crossing narrative. Progressive has repeatedly requested bodycam footage to verify the scene’s statements and is advocating for their insured while maintaining its liability position, subject to the bodycam review.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. The matter centers on correspondence related to Progressive file 23-6275504 and involves attorney Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm and Progressive Claims Specialist Amy Morris, with Greg and Cecelia Neltner as the affected party.

On December 6, 2023, at 4:19 PM (Eastern Time), Aaron Whaley sent an external email to Amy Morris requesting that Progressive share the photos from the scene. Whaley stated that he had Greg and Cecelia Neltner’s statements and that Progressive had its own insurance statement. He noted that all parties agree the incident was a rear-end collision, and that the sole dispute concerns whether Progressive’s insured drove across three lanes of traffic to pull in front of his client; Whaley asserted that the insured’s police statement admitting the lane-crossing is strong and admissible evidence. He asked how the time and location of the loss could be wrong and commented that, in the end, it would be his client’s word and the police officer’s word against the insured’s.

Amy Morris replied later that day, explaining that there are discrepancies in the police report regarding the time and location of the loss. She stated that their insured claimed they were sitting still at a red light when rear-ended, and that Progressive’s damage photos support a direct rear-end collision. Based on the information available, she said Progressive was standing by its liability denial and requested any evidence from Whaley to review in support of the other stance.

Earlier communications in the thread show Whaley’s prior exchanges. On November 30, 2023, at 4:15 PM, Whaley thanked Morris for the update and referenced an attached response to an open records request. He indicated that there was no body camera footage and emphasized that the police report was the crucial document, detailing what the insured said to the officer at the scene and aligning with both the insured’s statement and Greg Neltner’s account. He noted that the police report stated Progressive’s insured “crossed three lanes of traffic to get onto the NB 75 ramp, and as she did so, she turned in front of” Whaley’s client. While the officer could not testify to what occurred since he did not witness it, he could testify to what the insured said. He pointed out that the officer based his liability decision on the insured’s statements. The recorded statement from Greg Neltner indicated he did not see the insured, and the accident report described the insured as having “suddenly turned in front of him, leaving him no time to react.” The damage to the insured’s vehicle was listed as 7 o’clock, which Whaley argued was consistent with the insured’s statement about crossing three lanes to the left.

In another exchange from November 30, 2023, at 3:58 PM, Amy Morris reiterated that this was a word-vs-word case. The insured claimed they were rear-ended, while the client stated he did not know what happened and did not see the other vehicle. Morris referenced a third version in the police report and reiterated a desire to review bodycam footage, maintaining that Progressive was advocating for its insured given the information available at that time.

Earlier emails in the thread include Amy Morris’s messages to Whaley from November 29, 2023, at 2:05 PM, in which she stated she had received a voicemail and that Progressive remained by its liability decision, awaiting bodycam footage for review. A prior message from November 9, 2023, at 12:24 PM noted that the reply was sent to Aaron Whaley on October 17, 2023, and acknowledged ongoing discussion about the file. On October 17, 2023, Morris attached a formal response to the demand for Gregory Neltner. And on June 28, 2023, Morris asked Whaley to provide an email address for Jessa, also including her contact information and signature.

The case file also contains standard contact details for the parties: Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone number 502-583-4022; Amy Morris of Progressive Insurance Companies, with address at 9520 Ormsby Station Road, Suite 200, Louisville, KY 40223, and direct lines and email as noted in the correspondences. The thread ends with Aaron Whaley’s signature block reiterating his firm’s address and contact information.

Date: Tue, 12 Dec 2023 13:44:09 -0500

Amy, thank you for the response. It appears the main discrepancy is that
your insured says she had been sitting at the light for a couple of
minutes, and the police report says that your insured cut across three
lanes of traffic to turn left. In doing so, she turned suddenly in front of
my client. In the absence of anything else, this would be my client's word
vs. your insured's word. However, when your insured makes the statement
that she had been sitting at the light for a couple of minutes, I will get
to call the police officer in rebuttal. He will get to testify to what she
told him at the scene. The police report makes it clear that the narrative
he put in the report came from both parties. Then it will come down to
whether the jury believes your insured over my clients and the police
officer. That is a tough position to be in at trial.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023 involve Greg Neltner and Progressive Insurance in a motor-vehicle accident matter identified as PROGRESSIVE 23-6275504. The core dispute centers on fault for a rear-end collision in which Progressive’s insured apparently crossed lanes to pull in front of Greg Neltner. Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm represents Greg Neltner, and Amy Morris is the Progressive claims specialist handling the file. The exchange spans multiple emails between October 2023 and December 2023, with a focus on conflicting accounts of how the incident occurred and what the police report shows.

The discussion began with an October 17, 2023 email from Amy Morris to Aaron Whaley and Justin Whaley, attaching Progressive’s formal response to the demand for Gregory Neltner. The thread then shows a sequence of later messages in which the parties dispute what happened and what the police report reflects. By late November and early December 2023, the disagreements had become more concrete: Progressive’s insured says she had been sitting at a red light waiting to turn for a couple of minutes, while the police report indicates that she cut across three lanes of traffic to turn left and, in doing so, turned suddenly in front of Greg Neltner. The parties acknowledge the collision as a rear-end event, but the implication is that the insured’s lane-changing maneuver is what caused the incident, a point contested by Greg Neltner’s side.

On November 30, 2023, Aaron Whaley asked Amy Morris to share photos, specifically inquiring whether the photos were taken at the scene. He stated that the evidence before them included statements from Greg and Cecelia Neltner and the insured’s statement, and acknowledged that everyone agrees it was a rear-end collision. He emphasized that the critical question was whether the insured drove across three lanes to pull in front of Greg Neltner, noting that the only evidence of that maneuver would be the insured’s statement to the police officer who prepared the scene narrative. He also pointed out that the officer could testify to what the insured said, since the officer relied on those statements in making a liability decision, and that Greg Neltner’s recorded statement indicated he did not see the insured. He highlighted that the accident report described the insured as having “suddenly turned in front of him, leaving him no time to react,” and he noted that the insured’s vehicle damage was listed as 7 o’clock, supposedly consistent with the cross-lane left-turn scenario.

Amy Morris responded on December 6, 2023, stating that the police report contained several discrepancies concerning the time and location of the loss. She summarized Progressive’s insured as claiming to be sitting still at a red light when rear-ended and pointed to Progressive’s damage photos supporting a direct rear-end impact. Based on the information available, Progressive maintained a liability denial and invited any evidence that could support the other side’s position for review.

On December 6, 2023, later that afternoon, Aaron Whaley replied, requesting copies of photos and clarifying that there was no body-camera footage available. He reiterated the evidentiary posture: Greg and Cecelia Neltner’s statements on one hand, Progressive’s insured’s statement on the other, with a consensus that the collision was a rear-end event. He emphasized that the crucial issue was whether the insured crossed three lanes to pull in front of Greg Neltner, noting that the only evidence for that maneuver was the insured’s statement to the responding officer. He described the officer’s liability decision as based on what the insured said and pointed out that Greg Neltner’s recorded statement stated he did not see the insured, which aligned with the police report’s account that the insured “suddenly turned in front of him, leaving him no time to react.” He also mentioned that the insured’s vehicle damage being listed at 7 o’clock would be consistent with her account of crossing three lanes to the left.

On December 12, 2023, Amy Morris replied that she had been out of the office on Thursday and Friday but would share the requested information if the other party would share photos of their client’s damage. She explained that Progressive’s insured’s statement differed from what was in the police report and that the other party’s client had not seen Progressive’s insured. She acknowledged a discrepancy in the reported time and location and described the police report’s sequence as Burlington Pike, then KY 18, then the off-ramp. She noted that maps suggested Burlington Pike is KY 18 and that the loss occurred at the light where the insured was waiting to get onto the ramp, calling that portion a confusing part of the narrative.

That same day, December 12, 2023, at 1:32 p.m. (approximately), Amy’s message conveyed her continuing concern about the discrepancies between the insured’s statement and the police report, including the location and timing issues, and she reiterated Progressive’s liability position for review upon receipt of additional information to compare against the insured’s account and any photos.

Finally, later on December 12, 2023, Aaron Whaley responded that the central dispute remained the insured’s claim that she had waited at the light for a couple of minutes, versus the police report’s description of her crossing three lanes to turn left and pulling in front of Greg Neltner. He stated that, in the absence of other corroboration, it would be a matter of the plaintiff’s word against your insured’s word, but if the insured’s claim that she had waited at the light for a couple of minutes were true, he would call the police officer to testify to what the insured told him at the scene. He noted that the police report’s narrative appeared to have come from both parties and that the ultimate question would be whether the jury believed Progressive’s insured over Greg Neltner and the police officer—a difficult position to be in at trial.

In summary, the record reflects an ongoing, back-and-forth exchange over fault in a rear-end collision between Greg Neltner and Progressive’s insured, with key evidentiary points centering on discrepancies between the insured’s account (waiting at a red light to turn, no lane-crossing), the police report’s account (the insured crossing three lanes to pull in front of Greg), the jurisdictional location sequence (Burlington Pike, KY 18, NB 75 ramp), and the availability of photos or body-camera footage to corroborate the narratives. The file also shows that Progressive’s counsel sought to rely on the police officer’s testimony about statements made at the scene and on the police report’s portrayal of the insured’s statements, while Greg Neltner’s side emphasized the consistency of their statements and the potential weight of the officer’s testimony, with the liability decision likely resting with how a jury would assess credibility.

episodes.natural_language: Case Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023 concerns client Greg Neltner. A new insurance note dated 2024.04.23 records that I spoke with the adjuster, who confirmed they have not received a Demand on Cecelia. I advised that a suit has been filed as PR, and that it is very clear that the insured 'STATED' she caused the collision by attempting to cross 3 lanes of traffic and turning in front of the client. episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on April 1, 2023, with Greg Neltner regarding a motor vehicle accident. A Bodily Injury Adjuster called seeking a rationale for pursuing suit. We advised the PR that her insured clearly admitted fault at the scene. The story told at the scene matches the events stated by the client.

The adjuster said she would discuss the matter with DC. She would like to issue a demand on Cecelia; they have only received Greg's #BI #Demand.

Cohara to several recipients: Bryce Koon at bryce@whaleylawfirm.com, Greg Neltner’s Filevine project email address GregNeltnerMVAZ3721957@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, Greg Neltner’s MVA address, and Sarena Tuttle at sarena@whaleylawfirm.com. Thank you.” The message includes image attachments referenced in the email (as indicated by embedded image placeholders in the header).

Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023 concerns client Greg Neltner. The note outlining the Neltner v. Cohara matter is drawn from an email exchange dated June 17, 2024, between The Whaley Law Firm and Richardson Law Group, regarding discovery in the case.

In the morning of June 17, 2024, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) sent an email to Josh Leckrone, Esq., a member of Richardson Law Group (771 Corporate Dr. Suite 900, Lexington, KY 40503; phone 859-219-9090; fax 859-219-9292; email josh@RichardsonLawGrp.com; website www.RichardsonLawGrp.com). In his message, which was cc’d to Maeve Weihl and Aaron Whaley, he stated that he had received Richardson’s letter and planned to have his clients’ discovery responses back to them by the end of the week. He also noted that, upon reviewing his files, it did not appear that they had received Richardson’s clients’ responses to the discovery requests that had been served with the Complaint, and he asked for guidance on when those answers might be expected. This email included a caution regarding external email and a standard attorney-client privilege notice.

Shortly thereafter, at approximately 10:06 AM, Josh Leckrone replied: “Bryce, we should have those to you this week.” His message was followed by his full signature block, which identified him as a Member of Richardson Law Group and provided his contact information (771 Corporate Dr. Suite 900, Lexington, KY 40503; phone 859-219-9090; fax 859-219-9292; email josh@RichardsonLawGrp.com; website www.RichardsonLawGrp.com) and a confidentiality/privilege notice common to the firm’s communications. The reply also carried the firm’s environmental reminder to consider printing less.

A short time later, at 10:07:30 AM, Bryce Koon replied to Josh with a brief, “Sounds good, thanks Josh.” The thread then includes the standard firm notices and confidentiality language that accompany these communications, reiterating the message’s intent and restrictions on distribution and use. The thread also shows that the communication was part of standard, ongoing correspondence among counsel regarding the discovery process in Neltner v. Cohara.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. This note concerns the written discovery requests from the defense attorney related to Greg Neltner’s motor vehicle accident case. The communication thread began with an email sent on Friday, July 12, 2024, at 2:34:17 PM Eastern Time from Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, to Cecelia Neltner and Greg Neltner, with Bryce Koon CC’d. The subject of the message was Re: Your Written Discovery Requests from the Defense Attorney.

In the body of the email to Cecelia, Sarena stated that they were needing copies of Cecelia’s driver’s license and/or state ID, a copy of Cecelia’s health insurance cards, and Cecelia’s records from Children’s Hospital. Sarena noted that every time they had attempted to obtain Cecelia’s records from Children’s Hospital, the hospital indicated that their authorization to obtain those records had been revoked by Cecelia. Sarena also advised that she would be sending documents for Cecelia to sign via DocuSign and instructed Cecelia to follow the prompts to execute the documents from any electronic device without printing them.

In the same thread, Sarena addressed Greg, informing him that they were also needing a few things from him. She said that they had sent Greg some documents via DocuSign for his execution but had not yet received them back. She reiterated the need for a copy of Greg’s driver’s license and/or state ID and his health insurance cards. Sarena additionally requested that Greg provide the name of his Primary Care Provider (PCP) and the names of any other doctors he had seen in the past twenty years or so. She closed by inviting either party to contact The Whaley Law Firm directly at (502) 583-4022, ext. 104, or ext. 114 with any questions. The signature block followed, identifying Sarena M. Tuttle as Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (D: 502-357-9971), office line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and email (E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com), along with a note to please use the new email address.

Later that day, on Friday, July 12, 2024, at 2:01 PM (time indicated with an uncertain formatting), Cecelia Neltner replied. She wrote that she had a lot going on and had lost track of what she still needed to do. She asked if it was possible for The Whaley Law Firm to send her the documents and/or a list of tasks she needed to complete, noting that her email was heavily backed up and she could not locate all of the firm’s emails. She expressed that receiving those items would be very helpful.

The thread also contains earlier correspondence from June 2024. On Tuesday, June 11, 2024, at 10:24 AM, Sarena Tuttle wrote to Cecelia. She thanked Cecelia and then explained that it appeared Cecelia had answered her father’s set of questions. Sarena directed Cecelia to review the initial email and to provide her own answers to the set propounded to Cecelia, emphasizing that the cover letter and the emboldened title would bear Cecelia’s name, not her father’s.

The chain shows an earlier exchange on Monday, June 10, 2024. At 11:44 AM, Sarena Tuttle sent Greg and Cecelia a message explaining that the attached Discovery Requests from the Defense Attorney in their claim had been provided. The message noted that there was a packet for each of them, and while the questions would be almost identical, each person should provide their own independent responses. Sarena requested that both Greg and Cecelia supply a complete list of the providers each had seen for treatment, including their PCP, and asked them to include a personal description of the accident from their own viewpoint. She welcomed questions and offered to discuss them further.

The thread also indicates that Cecelia had sent a message on Monday, June 10, 2024, at 7:09 PM, though the contents of that message are not shown in the record excerpt provided.

The contact information for Sarena M. Tuttle, as listed in the signature blocks, includes her role as Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), the direct line (D: 502-357-9971), the office line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and the email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating a new email address. The Whaley Law Firm’s general contact details, including the phone number for general inquiries and the extension numbers referenced above, are consistently referenced across the messages.

The client continues to report that DocuSign will not let him access the document, even though several DocuSign requests have been sent without issue. episodes.natural_language:
This note concerns the case Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023, specifically Neltner v. Cohara, for client Greg Neltner. The communications reflect efforts to schedule depositions in the related matter.

On August 14, 2024, Katie Nelson, an associate at Richardson Law Group, reached out to Sarena Tuttle to follow up on scheduling depositions. Katie asked Sarena to provide a few dates in mid to late September when their clients would be available for depositions. The message included Katie’s request to identify suitable dates for the depositions.

In response, sent on August 19, 2024, Sarena Tuttle indicated that their calendar was pretty open for September. She asked Katie to confirm which of the listed dates would be available for both the Plaintiff and Defendant depositions, and she provided the following dates: September 3, 4, 11, 12, 17, 24, 25, and 26. Her reply came with her role noted as Litigation Paralegal and Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and she reiterated the need to coordinate availability for both sides.

On August 21, 2024, Katie Nelson replied with proposed specifics. She stated that her client’s deposition was available in the afternoon on either September 17 or September 25. She proposed hosting the depositions at Richardson Law Group’s office in Ft. Mitchell, Kentucky, with Plaintiff depositions beginning at 10:00 AM and her client’s deposition to follow at 1:00 PM or shortly thereafter.

The correspondence reflects accompanying email notices and standard confidentiality disclosures common to electronic communications, as well as the contact details for the sending and receiving offices. The participants included Katie Nelson (Richardson Law Group) and Sarena Tuttle (The Whaley Law Firm), with several CC’d colleagues from both firms. The case title, dates, and deposition logistics are all consistent with coordinating Plaintiff and Defendant depositions for the Neltner v. Cohara matter.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. Re: Neltner v. Cohara.

Between mid-August and late August 2024, the parties coordinated deposition dates for the Neltner v. Cohara matter. On August 14, 2024, Katie Nelson, an associate with Richardson Law Group, followed up with Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, asking for a few mid- to late-September dates when the plaintiff and, if possible, the defendant could be available for depositions.

Sarena Tuttle replied on August 19, 2024, noting that her calendar was pretty open for September and asking Katie to confirm which of the dates Sept 3, 4, 11, 12, 17, 24, 25, or 26 would work for both the Plaintiff and Defendant depositions. In her signature she identified herself as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and included her contact details, with an explicit “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

On August 21, 2024, at 3:31 PM, Katie Nelson responded with specifics: her client would be available for the deposition in the afternoon on either September 17 or September 25, and Richardson Law Group was willing to host the depositions at their office in Ft. Mitchell, starting with the Plaintiff depositions at 10:00 AM, with her client’s deposition to follow at 1:00 PM or shortly thereafter. Katie’s signature block included her title (Associate), office address (334 Beechwood Road Suite 304, Ft. Mitchell, KY 41017), phone and fax numbers, email (KNelson@RichardsonLawGrp.com), and website (www.RichardsonLawGrp.com). The message also contained the standard environmental note and a confidentiality notice typical of electronic mail transmissions, along with the customary guidance to contact Richardson Law Group if the message was received in error.

Earlier in the thread, on August 14, 2024, Katie had asked for dates in mid- to late September for depositions, and on August 19, 2024, Sarena had provided the open-availability window and listed the candidate dates for depositions as Sept 3, 4, 11, 12, 17, 24, 25, and 26, inviting confirmation of which of those would accommodate both the Plaintiff and Defendant depositions. The August 21 exchanges reflect a plan to host depositions at Richardson Law Group’s Ft. Mitchell office, with the Whaley clients located about 15–20 minutes from that office, and a scheduling question about whether two plaintiff depositions could fit in a 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM block or if only Greg Neltner’s deposition would be pursued.

In summary, the depositions were being arranged with the understanding that the plaintiff would be deposed in the afternoon on September 17 or 25, the firm hoping to host at the Richardson office, and the 10:00 AM plaintiff deposition and a 1:00 PM defendant deposition (Greg Neltner) or close timing were contemplated, subject to final confirmation of dates.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. This matter concerns Neltner v. Cohara.

The exchange of scheduling emails began with Katie Nelson, an associate at Richardson Law Group, sending to Sarena Tuttle at The Whaley Law Firm on August 14, 2024. In that message, Katie followed up on Maeve’s earlier email regarding scheduling depositions and asked Sarena to provide a few dates in mid to late September when their clients would be available for deposition of both sides. Katie’s signature included her contact information and a standard environment notice, and the message carried Richardson Law Group’s confidentiality disclaimer as well as the typical email disclaimers about privileged information.

On August 19, 2024 at 11:36 AM, Sarena Tuttle replied that their calendar was pretty open for September and asked Katie to confirm which of the dates listed would work for both the Plaintiff and Defendant depositions. She provided a list of available dates: September 3, 4, 11, 12, 17, 24, 25, and 26. Sarena’s email also included her contact information for the Whaley Law Firm and the standard external email caution, noting that the message was from an attorney at The Whaley Law Firm with the typical confidentiality and forwarding restrictions.

A subsequent email from Katie on August 21, 2024 at 3:31 PM stated that her client would be available for the deposition on the afternoon of either September 17 or September 25. Katie indicated a preference to host the depositions at their office in Ft. Mitchell and proposed starting with Plaintiff depositions at 10:00 AM, with her client’s deposition to follow at 1:00 PM or shortly thereafter. Katie’s signature again included her office address at 334 Beechwood Road, Suite 304, Ft. Mitchell, KY 41017, along with phone and fax numbers and her Richardson Law Group website. The email also carried the usual confidentiality notice and environmental reminder.

Sarena answered on August 21, 2024 at 3:36 PM, confirming that either of those September days would work for them and that they were happy to visit Katie’s office for the day. She noted that their clients are only about 15–20 minutes from Katie’s office and asked whether scheduling from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM would be enough time for two Plaintiff depositions, or if Katie preferred to depose only Greg. Sarena also attached her own signature block with The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and an indication to watch for the new email address, along with the standard external email notice.

Later on the same day, August 21, 2024 at 8:05 PM, Katie sent a follow-up reiterating and adjusting the plan. She proposed starting with Greg’s deposition at 10:00 AM and Cecilia’s deposition starting at noon, with her own client available for a 2:00–3:00 PM start time. Katie added that her client could be available for a 2–3 PM start time, and she reaffirmed the possibility of hosting the depositions at their Ft. Mitchell office. Her signature block again provided the Richardson Law Group contact details and the usual notices about confidentiality and environment.

Throughout these exchanges, all emails included the standard notices typical of confidential attorney communications, including warnings against forwarding to unauthorized recipients, and several messages referenced external email cautions. The correspondents repeatedly discussed scheduling two plaintiff depositions in September, with the ongoing consideration of whether the depositions could be conducted in a single day at Katie’s Ft. Mitchell office or whether only Greg’s deposition should be taken on a given day, and they settled on tentative windows that would accommodate both Greg Neltner and the co-plaintiff (Cecilia) as needed.

In summary, the parties were coordinating depositions in the Neltner v. Cohara matter, with proposed September dates including the 17th and 25th, and a plan to conduct at least Greg Neltner’s deposition at 10:00 AM and Cecilia’s at noon, followed by another session (2:00–3:00 PM) if needed. The depositions were to be hosted at the Richardson Law Group office in Ft. Mitchell, Kentucky, with both sides’ counsel confirming travel proximity (15–20 minutes apart) and capacity to complete the depositions within the day’s schedule.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. This matter concerns Neltner v. Cohara, with planning communications among the parties’ counsel in August 2024 regarding depositions.

The scheduling dialogue began with Katie Nelson of Richardson Law Group sending an inquiry on August 14, 2024, asking Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal at The Whaley Law Firm, to provide a few mid- to late-September dates when the clients would be available for their depositions. Katie’s message requested dates in that window so depositions could be arranged.

On August 19, 2024, Sarena replied that their calendar was fairly open for September and provided a list of potential dates for depositions: September 3, 4, 11, 12, 17, 24, 25, and 26. She asked which of those dates would work for both the Plaintiff and Defendant depositions. Sarena signed with her Whaley Law Firm contact information, noting her new email address.

The discussion continued on August 21, 2024, when Katie proposed a plan for depositions on the afternoon of either September 17 or September 25. She stated that they were open to hosting the depositions at their office in Ft. Mitchell, Kentucky, and that they would begin with Plaintiff depositions at 10:00 AM, with her client’s deposition to follow at 1:00 PM or shortly thereafter.

Later that same day, at 3:36 PM, Sarena responded that either of those September days would work for them and that they were happy to visit Richardson Law Group’s office for the day, noting that their clients were about 15–20 minutes from the other office. She asked whether a window of 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM would be sufficient to conduct two Plaintiff depositions or if Richardson preferred to depose only Greg.

At 4:06 PM, August 21, Katie replied, proposing to begin with Greg’s deposition at 10:00 AM and to have Cecilia’s deposition start at noon. She added that her client could be available for a 2:00–3:00 PM start time if needed. Her message also included her standard contact details and a note about environmental considerations for printing.

Finally, on August 22, 2024, at 10:10 AM, Sarena wrote back: “Awesome. I will notice Mrs. Cohara at 2:00 PM. Hopefully, that will give you all some time for a short break or lunch if you finish earlier.” She again included her contact information and noted the new email address.

In summary, the parties discussed scheduling two plaintiff depositions—likely Greg Neltner and Cecilia—on mid- to late September, with a plan to host the depositions at Richardson Law Group’s Ft. Mitchell office. The proposed structure was to start with Greg at 10:00 AM, Cecilia at noon, and to consider a potential 2:00–3:00 PM start for the defendant’s deposition if needed. The final confirmed note indicates a 2:00 PM deposition for Mrs. Cohara, with accommodations for breaks if the day runs long.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. This note summarizes the deposition scheduling discussions in Neltner v. Cohara, a motor vehicle accident case involving Greg Neltner, with communications between Katherine (Katie) Nelson of Richardson Law Group and Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm.

The scheduling dialogue began with Katie Nelson’s email on August 14, 2024, requesting Sarena Tuttle to provide several mid- to late-September dates when both the plaintiff and defendant could be deposed. Katie asked for a few options in that window so depositions could be arranged.

On August 19, 2024, Sarena replied that their calendar was relatively open for September and asked Katie to confirm which of the following dates would work for depositions for both parties: September 3, 4, 11, 12, 17, 24, 25, and 26.

Katie responded on August 21, 2024, stating that the plaintiff’s deposition would be in the afternoon on either September 17 or September 25. She also indicated a willingness to host the depositions at Richardson’s Ft. Mitchell, Kentucky office, with the plan to begin with the Plaintiff depositions at 10:00 AM and have her client’s deposition follow at 1:00 PM or shortly thereafter.

Later on August 21, 2024, Sarena replied that either of those days would work for their side and that they were amenable to visiting Katie’s office for the day. She noted that their clients were only about 15–20 minutes from Katie’s office and asked whether a 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM window would be sufficient for two Plaintiff depositions or if Katie preferred to depose only Greg.

Katie then clarified in a follow-up email on August 21, 2024 that they would start with Greg’s deposition at 10:00 AM and plan Cecilia’s deposition to begin at noon. She added that her client could be available for a 2:00 to 3:00 PM start time.

Sarena responded on August 22, 2024, confirming the plan and stating she would notice Mrs. Cohara for a 2:00 PM deposition. She also remarked that this scheduling would hopefully allow time for a short break or lunch if they finished earlier.

Katie closed with a brief acknowledgment: “Sounds good. Thanks Sarena.”

Accompanying these exchanges, the record shows that Sarena’s email address had changed to Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and the firm’s contact details were listed in the communications, including the Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line and other contact information, along with the new signature and standard environment notices common to the firm’s emails. The exchanges reflect the collaborative effort to coordinate depositions for both the plaintiff and defendant in September, with proposed timing that includes Greg Neltner’s deposition at 10:00 AM, Cecilia’s deposition around noon, and Mrs. Cohara’s deposition at 2:00 PM, all to be conducted or noticed in connection with the Neltner v. Cohara matter.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. Re: Neltner v. Cohara. The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, emailed Katie Nelson of Richardson Law Group on August 23, 2024, to clarify which deposition date had been agreed upon, noting that she had begun drafting a notice but did not see a final date. Her message also listed her contact information and new email address, and she copied Maeve Weihl, Josh Leckrone, Bryce Koon, and agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com.

The surrounding email thread shows the deposition planning spanning several days in August 2024. In an earlier exchange, Katie Nelson replied, “Sounds good. Thanks Sarena.” The thread contains additional correspondence with standard firm email signatures and notices, including the Richardson Law Group’s Ft. Mitchell office details and the Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville address. In one Aug. 22 message, Sarena replied, “Awesome. I will notice Mrs. Cohara at 2pm. Hopefully, that will give you all some time for a short break or lunch if you finish earlier.” Katie’s messages in the same period indicated initial scheduling thoughts for depositions and reaffirmed the plan to host the depositions at the Richardson Law Group office in Ft. Mitchell, with times to accommodate both sides.

Prior planning dates appear in the August 19, 2024 message from Sarena. She stated that their calendar was fairly open for September and asked Katie to confirm which of the following dates would be available for both the Plaintiff and Defendant depositions: September 3, 4, 11, 12, 17, 24, 25, and 26. Earlier on August 21, Katie had proposed that the plaintiff’s deposition occur in the afternoon of either September 17 or September 25, with the firm offering to host the depositions at their Ft. Mitchell office, starting with the Plaintiff depositions at 10:00 a.m. and the defendant’s deposition to follow at 1:00 p.m or shortly thereafter. In another Aug. 21 message, Katie suggested starting with Greg’s deposition at 10:00 a.m. and planning Cecilia’s deposition to begin at noon, with her client available for a 2:00–3:00 p.m. start time.

The practical scheduling details in the chain reflect that the depositions were intended to be held at timelines centered on 10:00 a.m. for the plaintiff, noon for another deposition (referred to as Cecilia), and 1:00 p.m. or shortly thereafter for the client’s deposition, with a 2:00–3:00 p.m. window available on the defendant’s side. The notes show ongoing coordination among the attorneys and staff at The Whaley Law Firm and Richardson Law Group, including the exchange of potential dates (Sept 17 or Sept 25 among others) and a plan to assign specific times and witnesses, with Mrs. Cohara slated to be noticed for a 2:00 p.m. deposition on the chosen date.

Key party and contact details included in the note chain are as follows: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line 502-357-9971, main office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104, and the paralegal’s email as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new address). The Richardson Law Group is located at 334 Beechwood Road, Suite 304, Ft. Mitchell, KY 41017, with a main phone number of (859) 444-4949, a fax of (859) 219-9292, and Katie Nelson’s contact email KNelson@RichardsonLawGrp.com. The emails also show that Sarena’s communications were circulated to Maeve Weihl, Josh Leckrone, Bryce Koon, and agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com, with notices reiterating confidentiality and appropriate handling of the transmission.

Cohara matter (Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023), the Richardson Law Group and The Whaley Law Firm exchanged emails in August 2024 to schedule a series of depositions related to Greg Neltner’s case. The attorneys discussed holding the depositions at Richardson’s Ft. Mitchell, Kentucky office, and considered dates of September 17 or September 25, 2024, with the plan to begin with plaintiff depositions at 10:00 a.m. and have additional depositions follow in the afternoon. Katie Nelson, an associate at Richardson, indicated that her client could be available for a deposition start time in the 2:00 to 3:00 p.m. window.

The scheduling dialogue evolved over several messages. On August 21, Katie proposed starting with Greg’s deposition at 10:00 a.m. and Cecilia’s deposition at noon, with “my client” available for a 2:00 to 3:00 p.m. start time, and she reiterated that the depositions could be hosted at their Ft. Mitchell office, with the plaintiff depositions beginning at 10:00 a.m. and her client’s deposition to follow at 1:00 p.m. or shortly thereafter. Earlier that same day, Sarena Tuttle from The Whaley Law Firm asked whether a 10:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. window would accommodate two plaintiff depositions or only Greg’s. Later that day, Katie refined the plan to start with Greg at 10:00 a.m., Cecilia at noon, and the client’s deposition beginning at 2:00 to 3:00 p.m. around the same date range of September 17 or September 25.

On August 22, the Whaley firm advised that they would notice Mrs. Cohara for a deposition at 2:00 p.m., with Katie replying that this was acceptable and that it might allow for a short break or lunch if schedules finished earlier. The exchange continued with the acknowledgment, “Sounds good,” from Katie. By August 23, there was still a request for finalizing the date, with Sarena asking whether the chosen date was September 17 or September 25, since she was preparing the notice. Katie answered later that day, definitively selecting September 17 as the date. In sum, the depositions were scheduled to occur on September 17, 2024, with Greg at 10:00 a.m., Cecilia at noon, and the remaining deposition(s) (including the client’s) to follow in the afternoon, and a deposition for Mrs. Cohara at 2:00 p.m., all to take place at Richardson Law Group’s Ft. Mitchell office. Participants in the email thread included Katie Nelson (Richardson Law Group), Sarena Tuttle (The Whaley Law Firm), Maeve Weihl, Josh Leckrone, Bryce Koon, and agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com, with contact details listed in the correspondence.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. Re: Neltner v. Cohara. On August 23, 2024, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Katie Nelson of Richardson Law Group with CC to Maeve Weihl, Josh Leckrone, Bryce Koon, and agwhaley, stating that their notice was attached.

The email chain begins with Katie Nelson’s message from August 23, 2024 at 9:50 a.m. In that message, she proposed September 17 as the deposition date, and she signed as an associate with her contact information and office location in Ft. Mitchell, Kentucky. The message also included the standard environmental reminder and a confidential, privileged notice applicable to the transmission.

Earlier in the thread, Sarena Tuttle had replied on August 23, 2024 at 9:42 a.m., asking Katie to confirm which date had been decided—whether the 17th or the 25th—as she did not see a final date in the draft notice.

The preceding messages reveal the plan developing over August 22–23. On August 22, 2024 at 10:42 a.m., Katie Nelson replied, agreeing with the plan. At 10:10 a.m. that same day, Sarena sent a message stating, “Awesome. I will notice Mrs. Cohara at 2 pm,” indicating the intended time for Mrs. Cohara’s deposition and implying that the other deposition times would be arranged accordingly. Katie responded shortly after at 10:42 a.m. with “Sounds good. Thanks Sarena.”

The conversation that preceded these confirmations began on August 21, 2024. At 3:31 p.m., Katie wrote to Sarena indicating that the client was available for a deposition in the afternoon of either September 17 or September 25, and that Richardson Law Group was open to hosting the depositions at their Ft. Mitchell office, starting with Plaintiff depositions at 10:00 a.m., with the understanding that her client could be available for a 2–3 p.m. start time. Sarena replied at 3:36 p.m. stating that either date worked for them and that they were willing to visit the Richardson office for the day; she noted that their clients lived only 15–20 minutes from the office and asked whether 10:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. would be sufficient time for two plaintiff depositions or if only Greg’s deposition should be taken.

On the same day, August 21, at 4:06 p.m., Katie responded, proposing to begin with Greg’s deposition at 10:00 a.m. and to have Cecilia’s deposition begin at noon, with her client available for a 2–3 p.m. start time.

The thread also contains the usual external email caution notices and signatures from both sides, including contact details and the reminder to consider the environment before printing.

In summary, the case involves the Greg Neltner deposition in Neltner v. Cohara, with planning to host depositions at Richardson Law Group’s Ft. Mitchell office. The involved dates considered were September 17 or September 25, with plans to start Plaintiff depositions at 10:00 a.m. and to schedule Greg’s deposition at 10:00 a.m. and Cecilia’s at noon, while a 2–3 p.m. start time was contemplated for the client. By August 23, 2024, a final date of September 17 was proposed by Katie, and a formal notice was to be attached to the email. The notice attachment was sent later in the day, and the correspondence included a standard confidentiality and privilege notice. The parties and their counsel remained in agreement on hosting arrangements and deposition timing, with ongoing confirmation of the final date.

Please check your email for our notice with additional details. - Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm”

The deposition has been scheduled for September 17th, 2024, with Greg at 10:00 am and his daughter following at 12:00 pm, to be held at the Defense Counsel's office. This notice was delivered to the client via USPS, Email & Text. The contact was made by Sarena on August 23 2024.

Bryce Koon, Esq. sent a message from The Whaley Law Firm ( bryce@whaleylawfirm.com ) to knelson@richardsonlawgrp.com, with cc recipients including the Greg Neltner MVA 4/1/2023 Filevine project email address (GregNeltnerMVAZ3721957@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com), Cecelia Neltner MVA 4/1/2023 (CeceliaNeltnerMVAZ3723199@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com), and Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com). The message was 19 seconds long and directed to the office line (502) 583-4022, extension 104, for Sarena Tuttle.

Accompanying the message were listening instructions: "Listen to this message over your phone or log in to your RingCentral account with your main number, extension number, and password. You can also manage your voicemails in your RingCentral account."

Client: Greg Neltner

In the matter of Neltner v. Cohara, the following communications occurred regarding the demand package. On November 6, 2024, at 12:16:53 p.m. Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email from sarena@whaleylawfirm.com to Mrs. Katie Nelson of Richardson Law Group, with copies to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com, Josh Leckrone, and Bryce Koon. The subject line referenced Neltner v. Cohara. In the body of the message, Tuttle stated that the demand package is in progress but noted that a message had been left yesterday requesting the name of the court reporter used during the Plaintiff Depositions. She indicated that the transcripts have not yet been received and that Whaley Law Firm would like to review and possibly reference those transcripts in the Demand. Tuttle asked Nelson to forward the court reporter’s contact information, so that Bryce Koon could reach out with an ETA on the Demand. Tuttle signed the email as a Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, providing the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line (D) 502-357-9971; office line (O) 502-583-4022 ext. 104; and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note acknowledging the address as the new email address.

Katie Nelson, Associate at Richardson Law Group, replied to the thread later that same day. In her message, dated November 6, 2024 (around 12:14 p.m.), Nelson addressed Aaron and stated that after the plaintiffs’ depositions in September, there had been a discussion that a demand package would be sent, but it had not yet been received. Nelson requested an update on the status of the demand package and asked to be informed if any additional information was needed from their side to facilitate the process. The message concluded with Nelson’s signature, listing her as an Associate at Richardson Law Group, located at 334 Beechwood Road, Suite 304, Ft. Mitchell, KY 41017; phone 859-444-4949; fax 859-219-9292; email KNelson@RichardsonLawGrp.com; and a website link www.RichardsonLawGrp.com. The email also included Richardson Law Group’s standard confidentiality notice, stating that the transmission is for the named recipient and may contain privileged or confidential information, and instructing the recipient to delete or notify the sender if received in error.

In summary, the record reflects an ongoing demand package for the Greg Neltner case, with Whaley Law Firm awaiting court reporter information and deposition transcripts to review for inclusion in the Demand, and Richardson Law Group seeking an update on the status of the Demand package and any additional information needed to facilitate its preparation.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. Re: Neltner v. Cohara.

In the matter of Neltner v. Cohara, communications on November 6, 2024, between the Whaley Law Firm and the Richardson Law Group illustrate ongoing efforts related to the demand package following the plaintiff depositions. The initial message in the thread appears from Katie Nelson, Associate at Richardson Law Group, addressed to Aaron (as referenced in the thread), with copies to the Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena Tuttle and others. Nelson stated that, after the plaintiffs’ depositions in September, the parties had discussed that a demand package would be sent, but to date she had not yet received it. She requested an update on the status of the demand package and asked if any further information was needed from their side to facilitate the process.

Sarena Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, replied to Nelson later that same day. At approximately 12:17 PM, Tuttle wrote that their demand package was in progress. She noted that they had left a message the previous day requesting the name of the court reporter used during the plaintiff depositions. She stated that they had not yet received the transcripts and would like to review and possibly reference those transcripts in the Demand. She asked Nelson to forward the court reporter’s contact information, and she indicated that Bryce Koon would reach out with an ETA on the Demand. Tuttle’s message included her contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note that this is the new email address.

In a follow-up message on the same day, approximately a few minutes later, Nelson replied, informing that Kentuckiana Court Reporters had been used. She provided their contact information: 877-808-5856. This information was given to facilitate obtaining the court reporter details for reference in the Demand package.

Later that afternoon, at about 1:14 PM, Tuttle responded with a brief acknowledgment: “Awesome. Thank you so much.” This closed the immediate exchange regarding the court reporter and the status of transcripts and the demand package for the Neltner v. Cohara matter, at least in this sequence of emails.

For context, the email thread shows that the first message in the chain originated from Katie Nelson and was sent to Sarena Tuttle, with additional CCs to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com, Josh Leckrone, and Bryce Koon. The subject line across the thread is “Re: Neltner v. Cohara.” The exchanges reflect coordination on obtaining court reporter information, transcripts, and ETA for the demand package, all within the framework of the Greg Neltner case concerning the MVA involving Neltner and Cohara.

This note documents an email chain related to the plaintiff depositions conducted on September 17, 2024 in Boone Circuit Court, case number 24-CI-00452 (103602), involving Greg Neltner as the client and the Nelter plaintiffs (Greg & Cecelia Nelter). The correspondence runs between Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm and Kentuckiana Reporters’ Transcript Department, with copies to Production at Kentuckiana Reporters, and includes a November 13, 2024 inquiry about the transcripts’ upload ETA.

On November 6, 2024, the Transcript Manager at Kentuckiana Reporters informed Sarena that, per the reporter, neither side had ordered transcripts at the time of the depositions. The department could proceed to get them in the works, but since The Whaley Law Firm would be the first ordering party, they would be responsible for the cost of the original transcripts. Sarena replied later that same day, stating, “Yes, please proceed,” and included her contact details with the new email address noted. The Transcript Manager responded at 1:44 PM that they would inform the reporter to get the transcripts in the works, and the message included the Kentuckiana Reporters Transcript Department signature, along with contact information: P: 502-589-2273; E: transcripts@kentuckianareporters.com; A: 730 West Main Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202; and the staff names, including Courtney Wiggins Madison Cyrus.

The initial chain also shows the earlier 1:31 PM message from the Transcript Manager, stating that, per the reporter, neither side had ordered transcripts at the time of the depositions. They could handle the order, but the first ordering party would be responsible for the cost of the original; they requested confirmation on whether to move forward.

Finally, on November 13, 2024 at 11:04:16 AM Eastern, Sarena Tuttle sent another message to the Transcript Manager asking for an ETA on the upload of these transcripts, noting that the attorney requested an update. Her message, sent from The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, listed her direct line (D: 502-357-9971), office line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and her new email address (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com). The message also carried the CC to Production at Kentuckiana Reporters and referenced the same case details: Plaintiff Depositions 09.17.2024 for Greg and Cecelia Nelter in Boone Circuit Court, 24-CI-00452 (103602). The chain includes the Kentuckiana staff signatures and identifiers, including Courtney Wiggins Madison Cyrus.

Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Discussed briefly w/BK - BK advised Companion (Daughter) was left with a scar & would like photos - Sent Text to Client requesting

Good morning Greg,
Bryce mentioned that Cecelia was left was a scar from her injuries, do you or her happen to have any pictures of the laceration at the time and/or currently that you could send us? You can simply attach them as a reply to this message & they will automatically upload to your file. - Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

__Date & Time__: November 13 2024
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on November 13, 2024, in the Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023 case, with Greg Neltner regarding a motor vehicle accident. During a brief discussion with BK, it was noted that the Companion (Daughter), Cecelia, was left with a scar from her injuries and would like photos. A text message requesting photos was sent to Greg. The message was sent by Sarena of The Whaley Law Firm and read: "Good morning Greg, Bryce mentioned that Cecelia was left was a scar from her injuries, do you or her happen to have any pictures of the laceration at the time and/or currently that you could send us? You can simply attach them as a reply to this message & they will automatically upload to your file. - Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm."

episodes.natural_language:
In the Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023 matter, the deposition transcripts for the plaintiffs Greg Neltner and Cecelia Nelter were taken on September 17, 2024 in Boone Circuit Court, in case number 24-CI-00452 (103602). The matter appears to involve the motor vehicle accident that occurred on 04-01-2023. The transcripts were the subject of a communications chain between Kentuckiana Reporters and The Whaley Law Firm regarding ordering and delivery.

On November 6, 2024, the Transcript Manager informed Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, that neither side had ordered the transcripts at the time of the depositions. The Transcript Manager noted that Kentuckiana could proceed with producing the transcripts, but because The Whaley Law Firm would be the first ordering party, they would be responsible for the cost of the original transcripts. The message asked whether The Whaley Law Firm wished to move forward.

Sarena Tuttle replied on November 6, 2024 at 1:41 PM, confirming, “Yes, please proceed.” She indicated that she was requesting the transcripts and noted her new email address. In a follow-up reply at 1:44 PM the Transcript Manager reaffirmed that, per the reporter, neither side had ordered the transcripts at the time of the depositions and that the firm could get them in the works; again, the first ordering party would be responsible for the cost of the original, and they asked for confirmation to proceed.

On November 13, 2024 at 11:04 AM, Sarena asked for an ETA on the upload of the transcripts and provided contact details for follow-up: The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct lines and the new email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. Later that day, at 4:09 PM (UTC), Kentuckiana Reporters responded that the transcripts would go out on November 15, 2024, stating this was in line with their standard seven-business-day turnaround. The message included Kentuckiana’s contact information and address: 730 West Main Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

He stated that the attached settlement demands related to his clients and provided a Dropbox link to related documents: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/5nupz6itm1mbeltt64vql/ALBI0GvICGuTGTTbDcYH1OU?rlkey=d171d463phglp9knrmx82b821&st=16y7liox&dl=0. The email was directed to counsel with copies to Cecelia Neltner’s Filevine project email address, CeceliaNeltnerMVAZ3723199@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, and Greg Neltner’s Filevine project email address, GregNeltnerMVAZ3721957@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, and it referenced the attached settlement demands and related documents.

On December 27, 2024, at about 11:31 AM, Bryce Koon wrote again to counsel to follow up on the settlement materials. The message read, Good morning counsel, Just wanted to follow up on these. Any update appreciated. Thank you. It was signed with his standard contact information for The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The email included the same attorney-client confidentiality disclaimer common to these messages, noting that the electronic communication is intended only for the named recipient and advising that if the message was received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and refrain from using or forwarding the information.

On January 7, 2025, at 3:28:45 PM Eastern Time, Bryce Koon sent another follow-up email to counsel with the subject line Good afternoon counsel, Just wanted to circle back on this one again. The message again came from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, with the same mailing address, phone, and fax numbers. It was addressed to knelson@richardsonlawgrp.com, with Cecelia Neltner and Greg Neltner copied to their Filevine project email addresses, CeceliaNeltnerMVAZ3723199@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com and GregNeltnerMVAZ3721957@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, respectively. The email again included the standard confidentiality disclaimer stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and that any inadvertent receipt should be reported to The Whaley Law Firm and not used or forwarded.

Throughout these communications, the underlying topic has been settlement discussions related to the Greg and Cecelia Neltner claim against Trinity Cohara in Boone County, with the November 25, 2024 message specifically attaching settlement demands and linking to related documents via Dropbox. The subsequent December 27, 2024 and January 7, 2025 messages show ongoing efforts to obtain updates or progress on those settlement discussions.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Neltner v. Cohara, a motor vehicle accident case identified as Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023, the client is Greg Neltner. On January 28, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, sent an email to Katie Nelson of Richardson Law Group (with several colleagues CC’d) stating that, after reviewing the claim, the deposition of Mrs. Cohara needed to be rescheduled. She requested dates on which Mrs. Cohara would be available to complete the deposition and move the claim forward. The message was signed with Sarena’s full contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting it as her new email address.

The email thread includes a prior exchange from November 6, 2024. At 12:14 PM that day, Katie Nelson wrote to Aaron (of the opposing side), noting that, following the plaintiffs’ depositions in September, there had been an agreement that Aaron would send a demand package, but none had been received yet. Katie asked for an update on the status of the demand package and whether any additional information was needed to facilitate its delivery. Katie’s signature block identified her as an Associate at Richardson Law Group, with the firm’s Ft. Mitchell, Kentucky office address and contact information.

Later that same day, at 12:46 PM, Katie sent another message stating that they had used Kentuckiana Court Reporters and provided their contact information: 877-808-5856. Katie’s signature block was included again with the same firm details. Across the thread, the images and boilerplate notices typical of email signatures appeared in the record.

At 12:17 PM, Sarena replied to Katie, explaining that the demand package was in progress. She noted that they had left a message the previous day requesting the name of the court reporter used during the plaintiff depositions and that they had not yet received the transcripts. Sarena requested the court reporter’s contact information and stated that Bryce Koon would reach out with an ETA on the demand. Her message included her standard signature and contact details, highlighting the new email address.

A follow-up reply from Sarena came at approximately 1:14 PM, simply thanking Katie with, “Awesome. Thank you so much.” This was also accompanied by Sarena’s full signature block.

In sum, the record reflects two primary threads: (1) a January 28, 2025 request from the Whaley Law Firm to reschedule Mrs. Cohara’s deposition and obtain dates of availability, and (2) a November 6, 2024 exchange concerning the status of the plaintiffs’ demand package, the court reporter used for the plaintiff depositions, and the receipt (or lack) of transcripts, with Kentuckiana Court Reporters named as the reporter service and contact details provided.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023
Client: Greg Neltner

Received nuisance offer from BI. They said there was still a dispute regarding liability - but their client didn't show up when we scheduled her depo before. Called DC and explained that we can't negotiate if they are disputing liability unless we can take their client's deposition. DC suggested mediation following defendant depo - said I wasn't opposed (but I don't really want to because Cecelia's claim doesn't meet threshold)
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact in the Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023 case was with Greg Neltner regarding a motor vehicle accident.

The matter recently received a nuisance offer from BI, which stated that there was still a dispute regarding liability, but their client did not show up when we scheduled her deposition previously.

I called DC and explained that we can't negotiate if liability is disputed unless we can take their client's deposition. DC suggested mediation following the defendant's deposition, and I wasn't opposed to mediation, but I don't really want to pursue it because Cecelia's claim doesn't meet threshold.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Greg-Neltner-MVA-4-1-2023. Client: Greg Neltner. Re: Neltner v. Cohara. The following notes summarize a sequence of email communications among counsel and staff concerning deposition scheduling and related demand package for the Neltner v. Cohara matter.

On January 28, 2025, at 10:29 a.m., Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Katie Nelson regarding the Neltner v. Cohara matter. In the message, which was also copied to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com, Josh Leckrone, and Bryce Koon, Sarena stated that, upon review of the claim, it appears the deposition of Mrs. Cohara needs to be rescheduled and asked that counsel provide dates on which Mrs. Cohara will be available to complete the deposition and move the claim forward. The email included Sarena’s contact information and noted her new email address. The subject line of the message was Re: Neltner v. Cohara, and the email carried the external email caution notice common to messages from outside the recipient’s organization.

Later that same day, at 3:36:27 p.m. +0000, Katie Nelson—an Associate at Richardson Law Group, located at 334 Beechwood Road, Suite 304, Ft. Mitchell, KY 41017 (phone 859-444-4949, fax 859-219-9292, KNelson@RichardsonLawGrp.com), with signature blocks and confidentiality notices in her correspondence—responded to Sarena. In her reply, Katie explained that they were awaiting a response from Mrs. Cohara regarding her availability and that she would send Sarena a list of dates that work for Mrs. Cohara as soon as they heard back. The message was addressed to Sarena and was CC’d to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com, Josh Leckrone, and Bryce Koon. It also included the standard confidential/privilege notice typical of Richardson Law Group emails.

This series of January 28, 2025, communications followed a previously ongoing thread from November 2024. On November 6, 2024, at 12:14 p.m., Katie Nelson sent an email to Aaron (the recipient referenced in the chain) regarding the demand package for the plaintiffs’ depositions in September, noting that the package had not yet been received and asking for an update on the status or any information needed to facilitate its delivery. Katie’s message carried her standard signature and confidentiality notice.

At 12:17 p.m. on November 6, 2024, Sarena Tuttle replied to Katie, indicating that the demand package was in progress but that they had left a message the previous day requesting the name of the court reporter used during the Plaintiff Depositions. Sarena stated that they had not yet received the transcripts and would like to review and possibly reference those transcripts in the Demand, requesting that Katie forward the court reporter’s contact information so that Bryce could be reached with an ETA on the Demand. This message was also marked as external email and included Sarena’s signature and new email address.

In a subsequent November 6, 2024 reply, at 12:46 p.m., Katie Nelson informed Aaron that Kentuckiana Court Reporters had been used and provided their contact information: 877-808-5856. Katie’s message included her usual signature and confidentiality notice.

Later still on November 6, 2024, at 1:14 p.m., Sarena Tuttle responded with, “Awesome. Thank you so much,” in acknowledgment of the information about the court reporter. This exchange also carried the external email caution and the standard Whaley Law Firm signature block.

In the same November 6, 2024 thread, the message from Katie Nelson preceding these steps reiterated her request for the status of the demand package following the plaintiffs’ depositions in September, noting that they had discussed that a demand package would be sent but had not yet been received and asking for any needed information to facilitate delivery.

Throughout these exchanges, the correspondents repeatedly attached their standard email footers, including confidentiality notices, and identified the relevant personnel, offices, and contact details. The core factual elements preserved in this narrative are the ongoing need to reschedule Mrs. Cohara’s deposition, the request for dates of availability to complete the deposition, the status and pursuit of a demand package from the plaintiffs’ side, and the identification of court reporter contact information (Kentuckiana Court Reporters, 877-808-5856) as part of those discussions.
